title: How are Korean names translated to Japanese? - Quora

response.answer_text: Basically phonetically, but with some quirks such as "li" often being changed to "i" for some reason (Update: Philip Newton has kindly explained this in the comments).Korean names are usually written in katakana in Japanese - they are sometimes also written in their original Chinese characters, but these are still read with the (Japanese phonetic approximation of) their Korean reading, as opposed to the Japanese reading (which is used for Chinese names). For example, the common surname "Kim" is written, in Korean, with the Chinese character 金. The Japanese reading of the character would be "Kin", but as a Korean name it's pronounced キム ("Kimu") in Japanese, in a rather unsuccessful attempt to mimic the original sound. Kim Il-Sung, for example, is famous enough that his name is usually written in Chinese characters (金日成) and people will still know how to read it (キム・イルソン, "Kimu-iruson"), but for lesser-known Kims, and most other names, katakana are generally used in order to make the pronunciation obvious.

Chinese character can be read directly into Korean or Japanese. simply write your korean name down in Hanja, have a japanese person read it and write it down for you in japanese. strangely the japanese readings are not one sylable per character like it is in china and japan so it may sound like they are wrong, but that is just how it is.
